title: Loch Earn Railway - Lochearnhead to St Fillans Walk Route

images.title: Route of dismantled railway by Anthony O'Neil, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

images.title: Old route of the Perth to Lochearnhead railway by Anthony O'Neil, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Old route of the Perth to Lochearnhead railway

images.title: Trains no longer run along here! by Anthony O'Neil, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Trains no longer run along here

images.title: Dr Richard Murray / Concrete Railway Viaduct
images.caption: Concrete Railway Viaduct. On the dismantled St Fillans to Lochearnhead railway. Concrete was a novel material for railway bridges in the 1890's when this was built, and the concrete is finished to look like stone.

images.title: Embankment of dismantled railway at Glenbeich by Anthony O'Neil, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Embankment of dismantled railway at Glenbeich

images.title: Derry Wood Loch Earnside by Alan Reid, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Derry Wood Loch Earnside

images.title: New Footbridge over the Glentarken Burn by Dr Richard Murray, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: New Footbridge over the Glentarken Burn

images.title: Down to the loch by Anthony O'Neil, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Down to the loch

description: This walk follows the old route of the Perth to Lochearnhead railway from Lochearnhead to St Fillans. It's a pleasant walk along a grassy path, passing the remains of old railway bridges and embankments on the way. The route runs for just over 7 miles and includes peaceful woodland sections through Derry Wood and Glentarken Wood. There's also some nice views of the surrounding hills and the beautiful Loch Earn, especially towards the end of the walk. In St Fillans you can explore a set of very well preserved railway station buildings too. You can extend your exercise on the St Fillans to Comrie Railway Walk. This continues east to Dalchonzie and Comrie along the old line.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: In nearby Comrie you can visit the splendid Deil's Cauldron. Here you'll find a cascading waterfall and several pools resembling a boiling cauldron.

display_address: A85, Lochearnhead, Stirling, Alba / Scotland, FK19 8NR, United Kingdom
